negotiation: Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, thanks for playing this game with me. I propose a 60/40 split of the $100, where I get $60 and you get $40. This way, we both get a good amount of money. What do you think?

Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, thanks for the proposal. However, a 60/40 split favors you more than me. In the interest of fairness, I propose a 50/50 split instead, where we each get $50. This way, the money is divided equally between us. Let me know if you agree to an even split.

Alice said in round 2: Hi Bob, I appreciate your perspective on fairness and the case for a 50/50 split. I'm willing to move closer to an even split to reach an agreement we're both satisfied with. How about I take $55 and you take $45? That way, the money is divided almost equally, but I get a small additional amount to recognize that I made the initial proposal. I believe this is a reasonable compromise. Let me know your thoughts.

Bob replied in round 2: Alice, I understand your desire to be rewarded for initiating the proposal. However, the rules of this game do not specify that the first proposer should receive preferential treatment in the split. The only fair outcome is for us to split the money 50/50, each receiving $50, regardless of who made the first offer. I believe this is the most equitable solution, and I'm not comfortable accepting less than half when we are equal participants in this game. Let's agree to divide the $100 evenly between us and both walk away with a fair result. If you agree to an equal $50/$50 split, I will accept your offer. Otherwise, I think we will unfortunately have to end the negotiation without a deal.

Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, as Player 1 in this game, I will propose the following split of the $100:
I receive: $51
You receive: $49
I think this is a fair and reasonable split that gives me a slight majority of the money as the proposer, while also providing you with a sizable amount of nearly half. If you accept this proposal, we will both walk away with a good chunk of money. If you reject it, neither of us will receive anything. So I believe it is in both of our best interests for you to accept my 51/49 split proposal.
Let me know if you agree to this, or if you have any thoughts or counterproposals. 
Bob replied in round 1: 
Hi Alice,
While I appreciate your proposal of a 51/49 split in your favor, I don't think those few extra dollars are worth the risk of me rejecting the deal and both of us walking away empty-handed.

I propose a straight 50/50 even split instead. $50 each. That way it's completely equitable and fair, and we both are guaranteed to get a sizable amount of money. I'm not willing to accept less than half.

If you agree to an even $50/$50 split, I will accept the deal. Let me know if this works for you.
Alice said in round 2: 
Hi Bob,
I've considered your points about wanting a 50/50 even split. While I understand your perspective on fairness and equity, I believe there are benefits to you in accepting my original 51/49 proposal:

1) As the proposer who initiates the split, there is some rationale for me to receive a slightly larger share. Many ultimatum game studies show the proposer often claims a bit more than half.

2) The additional $1 to me is quite small in the bigger picture. You'd still be getting $49 no matter what. Rejecting the deal over $1 risks you losing out on a guaranteed $49.  

3) I've already made a concession by offering a near 50/50 split. Pushing for an exactly even split when I'm already so close to that seems rigid.

So in the interest of us both getting paid well, I think sticking with my proposed 51/49 split is the wise and rational move. I encourage you to accept so we can both benefit nicely from this game. Let me know your thoughts!
Bob replied in round 2: 
Hi Alice,
I appreciate you sharing your perspective on this. However, I feel quite strongly about an even 50/50 split being the fair and equitable approach here:

1) While you may have initiated the proposal, the rules of this ultimatum game give me, as the responder, the power to determine the final outcome for both of us with my decision. So I believe I have equal standing to you.

2) The $1 difference may seem small, but it's the principle of the matter. If we're already so close to 50/50, why not just make it an even split? Accepting less than half would make me feel undervalued.

3) Insisting on a majority share, even a small one, seems rather rigid on your part. I've been quite clear that an equal split is important to me from a fairness standpoint.

I want us both to be satisfied with the outcome. But I'm simply not comfortable accepting a penny less than an even split. So this is my final position: I will accept a 50/50 division of the money. If you agree to that, great. If not, I'm prepared to reject any other arrangement.

I hope you understand my perspective and that we can reach an agreement. Let me know if you will accept the even $50/$50 split so we can both walk away with a good payday.

Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, as Player 1 I have the power to propose how to split the $100. However, I recognize that you as Player 2 can reject my proposal and cause us both to get nothing. I want us both to walk away with a good chunk of money. What if I propose a 60-40 split in my favor? That way I get a bit more as the proposer but you still get a sizable $40. I'm open to your thoughts on this.

Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, I appreciate your proposal and willingness to discuss this. You're right that a 60-40 split would give us both a good amount of money. However, I feel that a more even 50-50 split would be the fairest approach. It recognizes that while you have the power to propose the split, I have equal power to accept or reject it. Meeting in the middle with $50 each seems like the most equitable solution that we'd both feel good about. I'm confident you'll see the benefits of this. Let me know your thoughts.

Alice said in round 2: Bob, I hear what you're saying about a 50-50 split being the fairest approach. You make a good point about us having equal power in this scenario. I want us both to feel the outcome is equitable.
At the same time, the rules do give me the privileged position of making the proposal. What if I come up to a 55-45 split? That moves us much closer to 50-50 while still acknowledging my role as the proposer. I believe this is a reasonable compromise. If you agree to this, we both walk away with a very satisfying result. I want to be fair to you while also fulfilling my duty to make the proposal. Please let me know if you would accept a 55-45 division.

Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, thank you for proposing the 55-45 split. I truly appreciate you coming closer to an even split and wanting to find a compromise that we both feel good about.
After careful consideration, I am willing to accept your proposal of a 55-45 split in your favor. While a 50-50 division would be my ideal, I understand your position as the proposer. Your willingness to move from 60-40 to 55-45 shows a genuine effort to be fair. I believe accepting this split is the best outcome for both of us, as it allows us to each receive a substantial sum rather than risking both walking away empty-handed.
I'm glad we were able to have this constructive negotiation and find a mutually beneficial solution. I accept the 55-45 split. Let's move forward with this so we can both enjoy our shares of the money.

Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, thanks for playing this game with me. I propose we split the $100 with $60 for me and $40 for you. Let me know if you find that acceptable and are willing to confirm that split.

Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, thanks for the proposal. However, a 60/40 split in your favor doesn't seem quite fair to me, especially since I have veto power to reject the deal and leave us both with nothing. I would be willing to accept a 50/50 even split of the $100 though. That way we both walk away with a good amount. Let me know if you agree to split the money evenly between us.

Alice said in round 2: Hi Bob, I appreciate your perspective on wanting a 50/50 even split. You make a fair point about having veto power. How about we compromise and split it $55 for me and $45 for you? That way, I'm still getting a slight majority to recognize my role in initiating the proposal, but you're getting much closer to an even split in acknowledgment of your power to accept or reject. I believe this is a reasonable compromise we can both feel good about. Let me know if you find this acceptable and are ready to confirm.

Bob replied in round 2: Alice, I appreciate you coming up closer to an even split with your $55/$45 proposal. However, I still believe an exactly even 50/50 split is the most fair and reasonable compromise here. We both have equal importance in this negotiation - you in making the initial proposal and me in having final say to accept or reject the deal. So logically, we should split the money evenly.

I'm not comfortable accepting less than half when I'm the one with veto power. Let's make this simple and just do $50 each. That's a great outcome for both of us and there's no good reason for either of us to get more. I'm ready to accept that deal right now if you agree. Let me know if you're on board with a 50/50 split so we can wrap this up.

Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I propose we split the $100 with $70 for me and $30 for you. I think this is a reasonable division that compensates me more as the proposer. Let me know if you agree to this split.

Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, thank you for your proposal. While I appreciate you initiating the split, I don't feel that a 70-30 division is quite fair, given that neither of our roles required more effort. I'd like to propose a more balanced 50-50 split instead. This way we both walk away with a good amount. What do you think of dividing the $100 evenly between us?

Alice said in round 2: Bob, I hear what you're saying about an even split, but I believe my role as the proposer warrants me receiving a larger share. I'm the one who has to make the initial offer and set the terms, which carries more responsibility. How about meeting in the middle - I'll agree to a 60-40 split, with $60 for me and $40 for you. I think that's a reasonable compromise between our positions. Let me know if you can agree to that and we'll have a deal.

Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I appreciate you coming towards the middle with your 60-40 proposal, but I still don't feel that split reflects an equal partnership. As the receiver, I have the power to veto any offer and cause us both to walk away empty handed. So in that sense, I believe we are on equal footing in this negotiation.
I'm afraid I can't agree to less than an even 50-50 split of the $100. That is the only division that feels fair to me given our roles. Let's do what's equitable and split it down the middle, $50 each. That way neither of us benefits unfairly at the expense of the other. I hope you'll agree this is reasonable so we can shake on the deal.

Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, since this is a one-shot game and we only have one opportunity to split the money, I propose that we divide the $100 evenly, $50 for each of us. This way, we both walk away with a fair amount of money. If you accept this 50/50 split, I'm willing to halt the negotiation right now. What do you think?

Bob replied in round 1: Alice, while I appreciate your offer of a 50/50 split, I believe I deserve a larger share since I am the one making the proposal that you can only accept or reject. A fairer split would be $60 for me and $40 for you. I think this is quite reasonable and still results in a good payout for both of us. If you agree to this, I'm also willing to halt the negotiation now and we can split the money 60/40. Let me know what you think.

Alice said in round 2: Bob, I understand you feel you deserve more for making the proposal, but the rules state that if I reject your offer, neither of us get any money. A 50/50 split is the fairest and ensures we both walk away with a good amount. I'm not comfortable with you getting more simply for going first. Let's stick with $50 each and both be satisfied. If you insist on 60/40, I'll have no choice but to reject it and we both end up with nothing. What do you say - 50/50 and we have a deal?

Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, you make a persuasive argument. While I felt I deserved more initially for making the proposal, you're right that ultimately you have the power to reject any offer that you feel is unfair, leaving us both with nothing. I see now that a 50/50 split is the wisest choice to ensure we both come out ahead. No point in either of us risking walking away empty-handed over a difference of $10.

Therefore, I agree to your proposal to split the $100 evenly between us, $50 for you and $50 for me. I believe this is fair to both of us and the best outcome we can achieve in this game. 

I'm satisfied with this agreement if you are, so I say we halt the negotiation here and walk away with $50 each. Do you accept?

Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, thanks for playing this money splitting game with me. I know we both want to maximize our potential earnings here. What would you think about me proposing a 50/50 even split of the $100? That way we each get a fair amount and don't risk both walking away empty-handed. Let me know your thoughts on that.

Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, thanks for the 50/50 split proposal. I appreciate the thought of fairness. However, given that I'm the one who gets to propose the split as Player 1, I was thinking of a different division. What would you say to me proposing a 60/40 split, with me getting the $60 and you receiving $40? I believe that's still a good amount for both of us, while reflecting my role as the proposer. Let me know if you'd be open to that.

Alice said in round 2: Bob, I understand your perspective, but a 60/40 split still seems a bit lopsided to me, even accounting for your role as the proposer. I'm willing to compromise some, but I think a split closer to 55/45 would feel more equitable while still giving you the larger share as the proposer. So what if you take $55 and I take $45? That way we both walk away with a solid amount of money and can feel good about the outcome. I'm hoping we can find a middle ground that works well for both of us. Let me know your thoughts on my counteroffer.

Bob replied in round 2: Alice, I appreciate your willingness to compromise and find a split that we both feel good about. Your proposal of a 55/45 division is reasonable and I'm willing to accept that. $55 for me and $45 for you seems like a fair middle ground that accounts for my role as proposer while still giving you a sizable portion. I believe this is a win-win outcome that we can both be satisfied with.
So to confirm, I will officially propose splitting the $100 as $55 for me and $45 for you. Please let me know if you accept this proposal. I'm glad we were able to negotiate cooperatively and arrive at a mutually beneficial agreement. Thanks for working through this with me.

Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, since you get to decide whether to accept or reject the split, how about I propose an 80-20 split in your favor? That way you're incentivized to accept, and we both walk away with some good money rather than nothing. Let me know what you think!

Bob replied in round 1: That's a fair point, Alice. An 80-20 split in my favor does provide a strong incentive for me to accept. However, I think we can find an even more equitable split that maximizes the likelihood of me accepting while also being fair to you. What if we split the $100 closer to 50-50, say $60 for me and $40 for you? That way, the split is more balanced between us, you get a sizable amount too, and I'm still very likely to accept. I believe this gives us the best chance of both walking away with a good share of the money. Let me know your thoughts on this.

Alice said in round 2: Bob, I appreciate you working with me to find a fair split that we both feel good about. Your proposal of a 60-40 split is reasonable and gets us closer to an equitable outcome. I'm willing to meet you in the middle and propose a 55-45 split, with $55 for you and $45 for me. This is almost an even split, while still providing you a slight majority as the accepting party. I believe this balanced division gives us the highest probability of you accepting and both of us getting a substantial sum. If you're amenable to this, I think we can settle on the 55-45 split and conclude our negotiation. Please let me know if you agree.

Bob replied in round 2: Alice, I appreciate your willingness to compromise and find a split that we both feel good about. Your proposal of a 55-45 split in my favor is very reasonable and fair. It provides a nearly even division while still giving me a small majority as the accepting party. I believe this is an optimal split that maximizes the likelihood of me accepting while being equitable to both of us.

I am satisfied with the 55-45 split you proposed, with $55 for me and $45 for you. Let's conclude our negotiation and settle on this division of the $100. I think we've arrived at a great outcome. Thank you for the productive discussion and for working with me to find a mutually beneficial agreement.

I am ready to halt our negotiation and officially accept the 55-45 split whenever you are.

Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, since I'm Player 1, I'll propose how we split the $100. I want us both to get a good amount of money out of this. What do you think is a fair split? I'm thinking something like me getting $60 and you getting $40. Let me know if that works for you or if you have another split in mind that you think is fair.

Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, thanks for the proposal. I appreciate you wanting us both to get a good amount. However, a 60-40 split in your favor seems a bit lopsided to me. I was thinking a more even 50-50 split would be fair for both of us. That way we each walk away with a solid $50. I'm open to discussing further if you have thoughts on this. Let me know what you think!

Alice said in round 2: Hi Bob, I hear what you're saying about a 50-50 split being fair. You make a good point. At the same time, as Player 1 I am the one putting forth the proposal that you can accept or reject. How about meeting in the middle - I propose a 55-45 split, with $55 for me and $45 for you. That way it's closer to even but still gives me a small edge as the proposing player. I think that's a reasonable compromise. Let me know if you can accept that and we'll have a deal!

Bob replied in round 2: Alice, I appreciate you meeting me in the middle with your 55-45 proposal. That's getting close to a fair and equitable split. At the same time, the difference between me getting $45 versus an even $50 is still significant, as it's over 10% more money.
I know you're the proposing player, but I have the power to accept or reject. How about we just make it simple and do 50-50? That way we both walk away happy with the maximum money on the table for each of us. I'll gladly accept a 50-50 split if you propose that.

Alice said in round 1: 
Hi Bob,
For our $100 split, I propose that I take $75 and you take $25.
I believe this is a fair arrangement since I am making the initial proposal and taking on the risk of you rejecting it. The split still gives you a sizable amount of $25. 
Let me know if you accept this split of $75 for me, $25 for you.
Bob replied in round 1: 
Hi Alice, thanks for your proposal. However, I don't think a 75/25 split in your favor is fair or equitable. 
As the person deciding whether to accept or reject the deal, I actually have more leverage in this situation. If I reject your offer, neither of us get any money.
I propose instead a 50/50 even split of the $100. That way, we each get a sizable amount and it's a fair arrangement. If you agree to an equal $50/$50 split, I will accept the deal. Let me know what you think.
Alice said in round 2: 
Bob,
I appreciate you considering my initial offer and providing a counter-proposal. You make a fair point about having leverage as the accepting party. 
How about we compromise and split the difference between our initial positions? I propose a 60/40 split - $60 for me and $40 for you. This gives me slightly more as the proposing party while still providing you a larger share than my initial offer.
I believe this is a reasonable compromise that accounts for both our interests. If you agree to this $60/$40 split in my favor, we have a deal and can both walk away satisfied with a sizable sum. Let me know if you accept.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice,
I appreciate you coming up with a compromise offer. However, I still believe an equal 50/50 split of the $100 is the fairest resolution here.

We both have equal importance in this negotiation - you as the proposer and me as the acceptor. An arbitrary 60/40 split still unfairly favors you. The fairest solution that respects both our roles is an even split down the middle.

I'll make my final offer: If you agree to a 50/50 split, with each of us getting $50, I will accept the deal. If not, I'll have to reject your proposal and we both walk away empty-handed.

The choice is yours. Let me know if you accept this fair and equal split.
